I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  a  proposed 
1. 
multitranche  financing  facility  (MFF)  to  India  for  the  Madhya  Pradesh  Energy  Efficiency 
Improvement  Investment  Program.1 The  report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance 
(TA) for Enhancing Energy-Based Livelihoods for Women Micro-Entrepreneurs, and if the Board 
approves  the  proposed  MFF,  I,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  to  me  by  the  Board,  will 
approve the TA. 
 
2. 
An  adequate,  better-quality  supply  of  electric  power  in  rural  Madhya  Pradesh,  where 
70% of the population lives, would spur economic growth and development. In order to ensure a 
good quality, 24-hour supply of power to rural households, the Government of Madhya Pradesh 
(GOMP) has been undertaking a distribution improvement program (feeder separation program) 
with  an  approximate  cost  of  $1,100  million.  The  first  phase  of  this  program  is  already  being 
implemented  and  the  MFF  provides  financial  assistance  to  the  investment  program  that 
constitutes  the  second  phase.  The  investment  program  will  install  separate  feeders 2  for 
households  and  irrigation  water  pumps,  install  high-voltage  distribution  systems  (HVDSs), 
provide  new  power  connections,  install  meters,  map  the  assets  of  the  distribution  companies 
(DISCOMs),  and  undertake  network  analysis  to  ensure  better  quality  power  supply  to 
households  and  the  financial  sustainability  of  the  DISCOMs.  Of  the  total  of  50  districts  of 
Madhya  Pradesh,  the  investment  program  covers  32  districts  served  by  three  DISCOMs: 
Madhya  Pradesh  Madhya  Kshetra  Vidyut  Vitaran  Company  (DISCOM-C);  Madhya  Pradesh 
Poorva Kshetra Vidyut Vitaran Company (DISCOM-E); and Madhya Pradesh Paschim Kshetra 
Vidyut Vitaran Company (DISCOM-W). 3 
 

II. 

THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
Sector  performance.  At  present,  power  supply  lines  in  rural  areas  supply  power  for 
both agricultural pumps and other customers. This mixed rural distribution network faces several 
problems: the overuse of subsidized electricity for agricultural water pumping leaves households 
with an inadequate power supply, and the unauthorized use of electricity causes the DISCOMs 
to  suffer  financial  losses.  Aging  and  overloaded  distribution  lines  and  transformers  result  in 
excessive  technical  losses  and  poor  quality  power.  To  prevent  the  overuse  of  electricity  by 
agricultural pumps and to reduce losses, the DISCOMs switch on the distribution lines serving 
the  rural  areas for  a  limited  number  of  hours  per  day.  The  existing  mixed-feeder  system  does 
not allow power to be supplied on a 24-hour basis to households and business establishments, 
constraining economic growth and development in rural areas. 
 
4. 
To  promote  efficient  use  of  groundwater  in  agriculture  and  improve  on-farm  water 
conservation  practices,  the  DISCOMs  supply  3-phase  electricity  in  rural  areas  for  8–10  hours 
daily. However, this constraints economic activities and the constant (24-hour) supply of quality 
power  to  households.  Attempted  supply  of  one  phase  power,  after  8–10-hour  supply  of  three 
phase  power,  to  reduce  overuse  of  power  by  irrigation  pumps  by  the  DISCOMs  was  not 
effective.  Separation  of  power  supply  lines  (feeders)  to  agriculture  and  other  customers  is 
necessary to ensure the 24-hour supply of power to households. Additional measures—such as 
installation  of  a  HVDS  and  metering,  together  with  better  system  management  practices—are 
necessary to reduce DISCOMs’ technical and commercial losses.

5. 
Policy framework. India’s economy grew at an average rate of 8.5% per annum during 
2006–2011; the Madhya Pradesh state economy, which grew at a lower rate compared with the 
nation  in  the  past,  has  grown  at  similar  rates  since  2009.  This  remarkable  growth  will  be 
accompanied  by  increasing  energy  demand,  and  ensuring  energy  for  all  has  become  an 
important policy challenge. The Integrated Energy Policy of India, 2006, envisages the adequate 
and reliable supply of energy in a technically efficient, economically viable, and environmentally 
sustainable  manner.  Moreover,  inclusive  growth  and  development  is  a  policy  priority  of  the 
Government  of  India;  in  the  power  sector  this  translates  into  equity  in  power  supply  quality  to 
rural and urban areas. The government’s rural electrification program—Rajiv Gandhi Grameen 
Vidyutikaran  Yojana—intends  to  expand  power  supplies  to  rural  areas  and  to  ensure  that 
delivered services are on par with those in urban areas. 
 
6. 
Guided by the National Electricity Act, 2003, GOMP undertook a broader set of reforms, 
including  unbundling  the  State  Electricity  Board  into  six  state-owned  companies;  tariff 
rationalization; sector financial restructuring; and significant changes in regulatory approaches, 
such  as  open  access  to  the  grid  and  power  trading.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
supported these policy reform efforts through a sector development program (SDP).4 To further 
consolidate  the  reforms  and  to  realize  the  benefits  of  the  improved  policy  and  institutional 
environment,  ADB  provided  an  MFF.5 The  last  tranche  of  the  previous  MFF  was  approved  in 
December 2010. 
 
7. 
Strategic  context.  ADB’s  strategic  priorities  in  India,  as  envisaged  in  the  country 
partnership  strategy  (2009–2012), 6  will  continue  to  focus  on  infrastructure  development  in 
energy  in  the  poorer  states  to  help  address  interstate  disparities,  build  capacity,  and  support 
inclusive  growth.  The  country  operations  business  plan  (2011–2013) 7 includes  the  proposed 
investment  program  for  improving  power  supply  to  rural  households  in  Madhya  Pradesh, 
enabling the rural populations to be part of the ongoing development process. 
 
8. 
Policy  reforms  and  the  investment  of  the  Government  of  India  and  ADB  improved  the 
Madhya Pradesh power sector significantly, and 85% of villages have access to electricity and 
60%  households  in  the  state  have  formal  power  connections.  The  financial  positions  of  the 
DISCOMs  have  improved,  but  they  are  not  yet  profitable.  Average  commercial  and  technical 
distribution  losses  were  about  39%  in  2005,  decreasing  to  32%  in  2010,  while  statewide 
collection efficiency increased from 88.6% in 2005 to 94.6% in 2010. Although substantial, the 
reductions  in  technical  and  commercial  losses  were  inadequate  to  make  the  DISCOMs 
financially  viable  and  the  prevailing  loss  levels  are  unacceptably  high.  Proposed  investments 
are an integral part of GOMP’s strategy for loss reduction and making the DISCOMs profitable.  
 
Sector  road  map.  Distribution  system  improvement  and  installation  of  an  HVDS  were 
9.

MFF. These investments were undertaken mainly in urban areas. While the distribution systems 
in  urban  areas  were  supported  with  the  HVDS  and  other  improvements,  the  Government  of 
India’s  rural  electrification  program—Rajiv  Gandhi  Grameen  Vidyutikaran  Yojana—expanded 
the power supply to rural areas. The recent expansion of the distribution network to rural areas 
with  long  low-voltage  lines  and  unmetered  connections  is  one  reason  for  the  high  average

distribution  losses  in  the  state,  despite  the  substantial  loss  reduction  in  urban  areas. 8 The 
project  preparatory  TA  estimates  show  that  average  distribution  losses  in  the  32  districts 
covered  by  the  investment  program  is  about  46%,  much  higher  than  the  statewide  average. 
GOMP’s  feeder  separation  program  sets  out  a  clear  road  map  for  distribution  improvements 
with the objective of reducing these high loses by separating feeders and installing HVDS. This 
will enable the DISCOMs to ensure a 24-hour supply of good quality power to households and 
other customers in the villages. Irrigation pumps will receive a preannounced supply of 3-phase 
power for 8 hours. 
 
An Independent Evaluation Department (IED) study9 on the SDP (footnote 4), concludes 
10. 
that regulatory  and  institutional  reforms  should  be  combined  with accountability  measures  and 
incentives to improve operational performance in the Madhya Pradesh power sector. Its follow-
up actions emphasize the importance of the restoration of financial viability, accountability, and 
improved  operational  performance  of  power  sector  companies.  The  lack  of  full  financial 
autonomy of the DISCOMs has been recognized as a barrier to improvement by the companies 
of their financial positions and operational performance. Among other measures, the IED report 
also  recognizes  the  importance  of  the  ongoing  investments  under  the  Revised  Accelerated 
Power  Development  and  Reform  Program,  installation  of  a  HVDS,  and  feeder  separation  to 
reduce distribution losses, which is vital for the sector’s financial sustainability.  
 
11.  Multitranche  financing  facility.  The  ongoing  feeder  separation  program  in  Madhya 
Pradesh  needs  flexible  financial  support  to  achieve  its  long-term  objectives.  The  MFF 
represents  a  slice  of  long-term  contract  packages  of  an  investment  program.  The  investment 
program is supported by necessary MFF elements, such as a policy framework, strategic vision, 
and sector road map together with a detailed investment plan. GOMP preferred an MFF rather 
than a project or a sector loan mainly because of the successful implementation of the previous 
MFF. 
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

The investment program’s broader long-term impact would be inclusive economic growth 
12. 
in rural areas of Madhya Pradesh through access by households to a continuous, higher-quality 
electricity  supply.  The  measurable  impact  in  the  short  term  would  be  the  24-hour  supply  of 
higher-quality  electricity  to  rural  households  in  Madhya  Pradesh.  The  investment  program’s 
outcome  would  be  improved  operational  efficiency  in  electricity  distribution  in  rural  areas  of 
Madhya Pradesh. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

13. 
The  investment  program  will  deliver  five  components:  (i)  separate  power  supply  to 
farmers  and  households  through  feeder  separation,  (ii)  installation  of  HVDS,  (iii)  upstream 
improvement  of  33 kilovolts  (kV)  systems,  (iv)  supply  quality  improvements  and  metering,  and 
(v)  enhancement  of  energy-based  livelihoods  for  women  micro-entrepreneurs. 10  Feeder 
separation  work  will  provide  dedicated  new  11  kV  supply  lines  and  rehabilitate  old  lines  to 
households  or  farms.  Installation  of  an  HVDS  includes  installation  of  11/0.433  kV  distribution 
transformers in new locations closer to the households, conversion of low-voltage lines to 11 kV 
lines,  and  upgrading  the  existing  low-voltage  lines  with  aerial  bundle  cables.  The  upstream 
improvements  in  the  33  kV  network  require  new  33  kV  lines,  upgrading  of  or  new  33/11  kV 
substations,  and  installation  of  33/11  kV  transformers.  The  supply  quality  improvement  and 
metering  component  will  provide  new  connections  and  meters,  and  undertake  overall

improvement of the network management through asset mapping, energy auditing, and network 
analysis.  This  component  will  fully  utilize  the  resources  provided  by  the  previous  MFF 11 for 
computerized system management and related capacity building. The social and gender outputs 
of the investment program include: improving access to business development services for up 
to  20,00012 microenterprises  headed  by  women  across  32  districts,  capacity  building  for  up  to 
1,000  women’s  self-help  groups  across  32  districts  to  deliver  these  business  development 
services,  and  awareness  building  regarding  household-level  energy  conservation  and  efficient 
electricity use. 
 
D. 
 
14. 
GOMP plans to undertake approximately $1,100 million in investments under the feeder 
separation program. The first phase of the feeder separation program is being implemented, at 
a cost of about $544 million, and the second phase will cost $556 million. The government has 
requested up to $400 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the second-
phase  investments.  The  investment  program  is  expected  to  have  two  tranches,  subject  to  the 
government’s  submission  of  periodic  financing  requests;  execution  of  loan  and  project 
agreements;  and  fulfillment  of  terms,  conditions,  and  undertakings  set  forth  in  the  framework 
financing  agreement.  The  indicative  investment  plan  for  the  investment  program  includes  two 
$200  million  tranches.  The  two  tranches  will  have  same  project  components  except  that 
improvement in 33 kV systems is only in tranche 2.

The  three  electricity  DISCOMs  (para.  2)  will  serve  as  the  executing  agencies  for  the

18. 
A  coordinating  committee  comprising  the  chairmen  and  managing  directors  of  the

monitors  the  implementation  of  power  sector  investments.  The  Madhya  Pradesh  Energy 
Regulatory Commission monitors the performance and improvements in service delivery of the 
executing  agencies  at  the  state  level.  At  the  central  level,  the  Ministry  of  Power  oversees  the 
state sector policy and investment program implementation.

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

19. 
Capacity  development  TA  in  the  amount  of  $1,100,000  equivalent  is  proposed  to  be 
provided  to  enhance  the  business  opportunities  for  female  micro-entrepreneurs  resulting  from 
the availability of power on a 24-hour basis. The TA will train women micro-entrepreneurs and 
women’s self-help groups as trainers and business service providers, and build gender-sensitive 
awareness  of  power  use  and  energy  conservation.  ADB  will  provide  TA  not  exceeding  the 
amount  of  $1,000,000  equivalent  and  GOMP  will  provide  $100,000  equivalent  as  in-kind 
support.  The  TA  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special 
Fund (TASF–other sources). A national nongovernment organization (NGO) will be recruited by 
ADB in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time). About 14 person-months of international consultant inputs and 35 person-months 
of national consultant inputs will be provided by the NGO to implement the TA. The NGO will be 
selected  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  using  a  quality 
cost  ratio  of  80:20  and  a  simplified  technical  proposal.  The  terms  of  reference for  consultants 
are set out in the facility administration manual (FAM).13 
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical 

20. 
The  investment  program  uses  an  effective  technical  solution  to  reduce  overuse  of 
subsidized power for irrigation water pumping in order to ensure a 24-hour supply of power to 
households. The same technology has been used in feeder separation projects in other states 
in  India  and  these  projects  have  demonstrated  that  this  technical  solution  is  effective  and  has 
resulted  in  significant  economic  and  social  benefits.  For  example,  a  feeder  separation  project 
made  a  24-hour  supply  of  power  available  to  rural  household  in  Gujarat,  which  resulted  in  a 
vibrant  rural  economy  with  higher  employment,  better  educational  opportunities  for  children, 
many  positive  impacts  on  women,  and  a  boom  in  rural  industries.  The  overall  impact  of  the 
feeder separation in Gujarat on the agriculture sector has also been positive. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

21. 
The  investment  program  is  expected  to  benefit  2.68  million  households  in  terms  of 
providing  a  good  quality  power  supply  on  a  24-hour  basis.  It  will  also  provide  1.3  million  new 
power connections. The investment program therefore enables a large number of households to 
improve  their  economic,  commercial,  educational,  and  entertainment  opportunities.  The 
additional benefits of the investment program include potential water conservation and reduction 

                                                
13 Facility Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

  

 

7 
 

in peak demand for power. Groundwater depletion in India, partly due to the subsidized power 
supply,  is  a  concern.  The  feeder  separation  allows  the  efficient  use  of  subsidized  power  by 
water pumps. Given that there is a large potential for on-farm water conservation, water use can 
be  reduced  without  affecting  crop  productivity.14 The  separation  of  agricultural  and  household 
feeders  allows  agricultural  consumers  to  be  supplied  during  nonpeak  hours,  reducing  peak 
power  demand.  The  investment  program’s  energy  efficiency  improvements  also  result  in  an 
estimated  carbon  emission  reduction  of  920,00015 tons  per  annum,  and  an  estimated  1,100  
gigawatt-hour power savings per annum. 
 
The  economic  viability  of  the  project  was  assessed  by  incorporating  the  benefits  of 
22. 
technical loss reduction and associated energy savings, incremental consumption due to the 24-
hour  supply  of  power  and  new  connections,  and  reduced  transformer  failures.  Using 
conservative benefit assumptions, the tranche 1 economic internal rate of return is estimated to 
be  20.6%. The  sensitivity  analysis  shows  that returns  are  robust  against the  main  risk factors. 
The  willingness  to  pay  for  24-hour  power  supply  for  households,  estimated  using  a  stated 
preference  survey, 16  indicates  that  household  benefits  are  substantial;  incorporation  of 
willingness  to  pay  in  the  economic  analysis  provides  a  much  higher  economic  internal  rate  of 
return.  
 
23. 
The  financial  viability  assessment  of  tranche  1  was  undertaken  considering  reduced 
electricity  purchases  arising  from  the  reduction  in  network  losses,  additional  sales  due  to 
extending  the  supply  hours  of  electricity  to  rural  consumers,  and  conversion  of  informal 
connections  to  formal  connections.  The  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  was  calculated 
following  ADB  guidelines.  The  financial  internal  rates  of  return  were  estimated  for  the  three 
DISCOMs separately, and all exceed the weighted average cost of capital of 3.5%. Tranche 1 
provided  a  financial  internal  rate  of  return  of  15.4%,  which  clearly  demonstrates  the  financial 
viability  of  the  project. The financial  management  assessment  shows  that  the  current financial 
position of the three DISCOMs is not impressive. None of the companies currently make profits 
and their debt situation is also not healthy. The business plans of the companies forecast profits 
in  2015.  Anticipated  loss  reductions  due  to  ongoing  and  proposed  investments  and  better 
financial  management  are  expected  to  result  in  improvements  in  the  companies’  financial 
positions. 
 
C. 

Governance 

24. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  GOMP  and  the  DISCOMs.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance, 
accountability, and transparency, implementation of the projects under the MFF shall adhere to 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy. ADB reserves the right to review and examine, directly or through 
its  agents,  any  alleged  corrupt,  fraudulent,  collusive,  or  coercive  practices  relating  to  projects 
under the MFF. In this regard, investigation of government officials, if any, would be requested 
by  ADB  to  be  undertaken  by  the  government.  To  support  these  efforts,  relevant  provisions  of 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy are included in the loan regulations and the bidding documents. In 
particular, all contracts financed by ADB shall include provisions specifying the right of ADB to 
audit  and  examine  the  records  and  accounts  of  the  DISCOMs  and  all  contractors,  suppliers, 
consultants, and other service providers as they relate to the projects under the MFF. Financial 
institutional  and  corporate  governance  assessment  undertaken  as  part  of  the  financial

D. 

Poverty and Social 

The  power  sector  has  significant  potential  to  contribute  to  economic  development  and 
25. 
social wellbeing, and is both directly and indirectly linked to poverty reduction. Stable electricity 
supply  promotes  the  agriculture  sector  and  business  expansion,  and  increases  employment 
opportunities,  which  will  have  a  positive  impact  on  poverty  reduction.  A  good  quality,  reliable 
electricity supply is also a key to meeting the basic human needs of health and education. Poor 
and  vulnerable  consumers,  as  well  as  public  utilities  such  as  hospitals  and  schools,  are  often 
particularly  disadvantaged  by  an  inadequate  power  supply,  load  shedding,  and  poor  power 
quality, and will therefore benefit directly from the investment program. The investment program 
is  expected  to  generate  considerable  employment  for  skilled  and  unskilled  labor  during 
construction.  A  household  survey  conducted  by  the  project  preparatory  TA  consultant  shows 
that  beneficiaries  believe  that  availability  of  a  24-hour  supply  of  power  will  result  in  children 
spending more time studying (60%), women spending less time on household tasks (30%), the 
purchase of electrical appliances to make life easier (28%), and people spending more time on 
leisure (24%).  
 
E. 

Safeguards 

that  can  be  readily  mitigated.  An

An  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework,  and  a  resettlement  framework 
were prepared outlining the environmental and social safeguard principles and requirements.17 
The  executing  agencies  will  undertake  environmental  and  social  safeguard  due  diligence  on 
subprojects  based  on  the  environmental  assessment  and  review  framework  and  resettlement 
framework  and submit  bi-annual  reports  on  implementation  of  the  environmental management 
plan  and  resettlement  plan  for  subprojects.  Tranche  1  is  classified  as  category  B  for  both 
involuntary  resettlement  and  the  environment.  The  proposed  project  has  no  potential  for 
significant air, water, or noise pollution. It does not fall in the vicinity of any natural ecosystems, 
reserve  forests,  protected  areas,  and  cultural  sites.  It  has  temporary  minor  impacts  during 
construction 
initial  environmental  examination  and 
environmental  management  plan  have  been  prepared  for  tranche  1  components  based  on

27. 
Tranche  1  components  will  not  require  private  land  acquisition.  Construction  of  new 
distribution  lines  will  be  pole–based,  which  will  have  minor  temporary  impacts  on  standing 
crops. Tranche 2 components will have 21 new 33/11 kV substations in the DISCOM-W area for 
which the sites have already been identified. Most of the substations are proposed to be located 
on  government  land.  The  lines  under  tranche  2  will  have  no  impact  on  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement  except  some  temporary  damage  to  standing  crops  that  may  occur  during  the 
construction. 
 
28. 
Tranche  1  is  classified  as  category  C  for  indigenous  peoples.  According  to  social 
assessments,  no  indigenous peoples  are  expected to  be  impacted  by  either  of the  investment 
program’s  projects  (tranches  1  and  2).  However,  an  indigenous  peoples  planning  framework 
has been prepared for the investment program. In the event of impacts on indigenous peoples, 
the  project  will  apply  the  mitigation  measures  provided  in  the  indigenous  peoples  planning 
framework  and  the  resettlement  framework,  which  include  specific  measures  that  provide 
entitlements  to  vulnerable groups,  including  indigenous  peoples.  Project  construction  activities 
are expected to be small in scale, with the possible involvement of local people in construction
